*Just another weekend ... with ultra-processed foods (UPFs). (generated by Google Gemini 3 Pro at Perplexity.ai)*

---

I've been skeptical of recent emphasis on **_ultra-processed foods (UPFs)_** and the sudden thrust of the topic into the limelight -- for example, [the Super Bowl ad featuring Mike Tyson](https://youtube.com/shorts/z0daqhK9tyg) this past weekend. Who's behind it, what are their ulterior motives, and who's incentivizing them? These are all questions I have. But, admittedly, I don't know much about the topic.

The BFIH analysis in this post helped me to understand the context, the players, the science, and the policy pushes.  My skepticism remains but it's shifted on to the specifics -- I'm doubtful that this is a genuine effort at the federal level to truly make a difference in people's lives -- not enough money and priority behind it -- and it's a very long shot that it will make a difference in long-term health outcomes, but we'll have to wait and see.

---

**The proposition to analyze:**

> **_"Ultra-processed foods (UPFs) are the primary causal driver of the American chronic disease epidemic, and policies targeting processing level (not just nutrients) will measurably reduce disease burden within a decade."_**

**The upshot:** Lays out some plausible tips for effective policy in this space. I hope such measures will be taken.
